article.title: The smallest space miners: principles of space biomining

funding.source: United Kingdom Science and Technology Facilities Council
United Kingdom Science and Technology Facilities Council

article.abstract: As we aim to expand human presence in space, we need to find viable approaches to achieve independence from terrestrial resources. Space biomining of the Moon, Mars and asteroids has been indicated as one of the promising approaches to achieve in-situ resource utilization by the main space agencies.

sections.introduction: As the goal for human space exploration moves farther from Earth, relying on a constant resupply of resources from Earth becomes less viable. In-situ resource utilization (ISRU) approaches have the aim of enabling sustainable exploration and settlement of space, by mitigating the need of importing goods and materials from Earth (NASA-ASEE 1992; Anand et al. 2012; Montague et al. 2012; Menezes et al. 2015b; Verseux et al. 2016).

article.insights_summary: Space biomining is a promising approach for in-situ resource utilization in space. It involves the use of microorganisms to extract valuable resources from planetary bodies. However, the science around space biomining is still young and requires further research to overcome the challenges of extraterrestrial conditions.
